title: How to tell when someone is trying to take advantage of you - Quora

response.answer_text: if he's not consistent texting you, calling you, and asking you out for proper dates, he's using you. Depending on your age, say you're in college, a date can mean a coffee at Starbucks. Of course, smile and say thank you and don't be a demanding shrew who feels entitled to a $200 dinner on a first date. Always have enough cash in hand to pay your way and get a cab home if need be. If he doesn't pay, don't make a scene or else you'll develop a reputation as a gold digger in your circles. Simply smile, pay for your portion, wish him a polite goodbye, and drop him. If a guy is truly interested in you, he'll happily pay for the date.If he goes weeks MIA and then randomly texts (usually at night) because he wants a booty call. Delete his number.If he asks for dirty pics. delete and block him asapIf he is inconsistent (see #1). No one is “too busy” to send a text. He is soooooo busy he doesn't have five seconds to send a text? Yeah I don't think so. When a guy likes you, he somehow makes time for a gal he likes.5. If he's been taking you out on a handful of dates for 1–2 months, you should know exactly where you stand with him. Does he call you his girlfriend? If he is hopping on one foot to the other, nervously bouncing around and unable to answer the question, he's using you and likely doing the same to other women. Drop him. 6. If he doesn't formally introduce you to his family and friends after a certain time period or doesn't want to meet your family. This is shorter time for Americans and longer for Indians, for example. But use your judgment. 7. If he doesn't do anything romantic for your birthday or Valentine's Day. If you're in college, a box of candy and some flowers should suffice. If you're 30, he needs to do that and take you out somewhere and do something special. If he completely ignores either occasion, he's an ass and you need to tell him “I'm sorry but this isn't working out”. 8. If he cheats, he's out. No going back. No sorry no tears etc. Ways to avoid being used…don't respond to night time texts. Delete and block any guy who asks for nudes. Drop any guy who wants a text message pen pal buddy. Don't get intimate too quickly. Drop any guy who doesn't pay for dates; the dates need not be lavish but if he doesn't have $15 to buy you a sandwich is he really in a position to have a girlfriend? Let him be the one to pursue. In the beginning, let him be the one to call or to travel to see you 2/3–3/4 of the time. Once the relationship is established, then it can be more equal. Don't move in with him until you're officially engaged. People something more when they have to work for it. Don't be a bitch but don't be too easy to get either. The way I'd sum this up is “a girl should be hard to get but easy to be with”. Don't accept a last minute date. You're busy and need at least two day in advance notice to keep him on his toes. Once on the date, however, be pleasant to be with; don't order the most expensive entree on the menu, don't complain about the place, smile at him, be polite and engaging, say please and thank you, and be gracious. Pick your fights wisely. Before starting a fight ask yourself if it's worth it. Is it REALLY a big deal that he got you lillies when he should know that you like roses? Hey, at least he got you flowers! Perhaps he insinuated that your hairstyle isn't to his liking. cmon! Give him a break. This does not mean you're a doormat. If he insults you or does something not ok, absolutely confront him.

People are often trying to take advantage of you and it’s not always a “bad thing”. People do things that work to THEIR advantage and for THEIR benefit. True altruism is rare. “Let’s go to Murphy’s Bar,” your friend says. Is it because he wants you to have fun or because he happens to like that bar, needs a drink, wants company or a wing man and so on? If he picks up a girl there and you’re left alone at the bar, have you been taken advantage of? Maybe. Were you harmed? Probably not. It’s not a “he wins, I lose” situation. Where people try to create a lose-win scenario such that you lose and they win is the problem. This is what you see when people try to manipulate you into doing something you don’t want to do so that they benefit. This can be for any outcome, from their entertainment in humiliating you to separating you from your money to getting you to do something they don’t want to do. Tom Sawyer suckered his friends into painting the fence for him in the famous book. Anyone who tries to question your manhood, cajole, threaten, humiliate or beg you into doing something you don’t want to do is usually doing it for their benefit - not yours. Sometimes they want you to pull the tail of the tiger so they can watch you be punished or humiliated. Sometimes they want you to participate in some activity to “spread the blame” or even bolster their own courage. However, sometimes, they are being altruistic and want you to step out of your comfort zone and grow. So even then you have to consider the outcome and the motivation. One of the things I often say on Quora is that one of the best things about being an adult is that you don’t need a reason to do or not do something. If someone is trying to cajole you into doing something you don’t want to do, simply saying “I don’t feel like it” is sufficient reason. They will plead for you to argue so they can knock down your arguments and do what THEY want you to do. But you don’t need to argue. You just need to say “I don’t want to.” The other thing you can do is walk away. When people are trying to manipulate you and are heckling you into doing their bidding you need only walk away. Developing friends, lovers, colleagues, customers and so forth is the result of a built-up trust relationship. You observe people’s behavior over time and you extend trust based on the results of that behavior. When you first meet someone you extend them “trust credit”, that is, the basic trust that includes not shooting/stabbing them on sight and believing they won’t do the same to you. You’re extending them trust they haven’t earned on credit. Their subsequent behavior allows them to either pay off that trust credit - or for you to revoke it and never turn your back on them or trust them or anything they say. We are doing this all the time. The clerk at the 7/11 is forced to extend trust credit to every stranger that walks in the door and he extends as little as his minimum wage pay allows because sooner or later he is going to be betrayed by a guy with a gun who wants to take advantage of him and rob the register. However, another customer who comes in day after day and purchases the same pack of cigarettes may get a rather large trust-credit such that the clerk might ask him to “watch the store while I take a leak”. He is taking a risk based on his observation of behavior over time. People who enter into romantic relationships sometimes fail to do their due-diligence in the observation behavior. Their hormones or desperation or desire cause them to make a crack-observation about someone and offer them, with no good reason, their entire trust credit line. Those people are usually betrayed. On the other hand, there are people who talk the talk and walk the walk just long enough to get that credit extended long enough to convince their mark to give up the thing they seek, be it sex, money, submission, whatever. They are “con men” and this happens a great deal. So-called “pick-up artists” are people who are adept at getting others to trust them quickly for the purpose of having sex and then running away. In reality, nothing is ever lost by patience in a real relationship and people who say things like “If you really loved me you would…” or “I know we just met but I feel so right, so strongly about you… if only we could…” are saying it to close the deal and get what they want. In building trust one watches how a partner acts in a variety of situations. How does he treat the receptionist? The car valet? The waitress? His mother? A store clerk who makes a mistake? Someone who cuts him off in traffic? A babbling mentally handicapped person? A homeless beggar on the street? A stray cat? A noisy child? There are no perfect people but how someone treats all these varieties is probably how he will treat you when the newness is gone. People don’t often change their behavior. They do what they’ve always done so they can get what they always got, at least for this moment. Even if it’s a losing strategy in the long run. There is an expression that goes, “It’s better to be sometimes cheated than not to trust.” This means that to move forward in life you have to take a risk. You have to decide to extend your “trust credit line” further than you might want to, even risk getting hurt, because the alternative is to live a life of fear and that’s no good either. You have to risk to make progress and often that means trusting. Sometimes you can only find out if someone is trustworthy by trusting them. You take the risk, maybe on the basis of a thousand unconscious observations; maybe on the basis that someone you trust trusted them. You have to do this or you would never leave the house. You would always be in terror of being cheated. In the end you are often getting taken advantage of when you feel badly about yourself or the outcome and don’t see any good coming your way. Sometimes it’s as small as a telemarketer soliciting donations for a fake charity or one that keeps 90 percent of the proceeds; there you can at least feel good that you meant well. Or it can be as large as someone who manipulates you so they can cheat on you, even after being with you for some time, for their own selfish ends. You were fooled and it’s not your fault. People often don’t remember what you say but they always remember how you made them feel. If you feel good about yourself, about what you’ve done, about the other person then you were not taken advantage of - even if you were - because you gained something of value, be it esteem, joy, experience, fun or comradeship. How you feel about the transaction often determines if you are being conned or not.

Think about if that person has ever specifically wanted something from you. They'd bring it up every so often. Sometimes subtly sneak it into conversations. Maybe even guilt you into doing it for them. Have you felt guilty after they asked for something and you didn't give it, even if it was justifiable and reasonable for you to not give in?Once you've given them something, physical or non-physical, you feel like you've lost something. You often think about taking it back or never have given it at all, and ruminate over what could have been done differently.They show little to no compassion or concern for you. You may shower them in attention and empathy, but in the end, they never ask how you are doing, what you've been doing, or just aren't that interested in you until you have something they want. They'll often switch subjects when you start to talk about yourself or things pertaining to yourself, or stare off into the distance, or even just leave. Bottom line is: they don't care, and it's not that obvious if you're infatuated/care about them until you begin to think about it.They stop talking after you've given them what they want. The calls, texts, everything just stops. Sometimes they'll text or call again when they want something again. They're pretty much professionals at taking advantage. Most of the people who take advantage of others have just grown up doing this and are pretty used to it, they usually think nothing of it. In their mind, you are just an object or obstacle in their path to get what they want, and if they want it bad enough, they'll pull out all the tricks. Remember, they've done this before. They'll be really convincing at the time and they'll probably leave you thinking, “is it right to question them?”Make a list of your doubts and worries about them. Sometimes writing things out can help you clear your mind of all those jumbled, racing thoughts, and get down to the facts. Write about times they seemed sketchy or weird, write every little detail that stands out. Then, slowly, just begin to narrow it down. Remember that people are imperfect, and everyone has their flaws, but when their imperfections begin to impact you negatively, you have every right to take a step back and set boundaries. Begin to realise that people only treat you how you let them. Begin to step back from giving away pieces of yourself to people who will only stomp on them. Begin to see these behaviors, recognize when others expect things out of you and ask yourself, “is this a reasonable expectation?” before you bend over backwards.Prevent it. Stop and think before doing things for others. If you have to think for more than a minute, you're probably putting yourself in a situation to be taken advantage of. Simply say no. That's your right. You may think about yourself as a bitch afterwards, but being a bitch in someone's mind is better than living with heartache and hurt.Value yourself more. Realise that you are worth much more than you think. Find confidence in yourself, start loving yourself. People are much more likely to take advantage of a person who is insecure or in a bad state of mind than a person who is confident and loves themselves. It's sad, but true. I speak from experience. People really don't mess with me now as much as they did when I was in the dumps. Just like the lions, the predators look for the weakest prey for a fulfilling and easy meal. Sometimes, finding confidence and self love requires counselling, therapy methods, and medications. All of it with be worth it in the end. Don’t give up on yourself, don't beat yourself down. Keep moving forward. Be hesitant in giving things to people who don't care about you. Look for the signs, always be aware. Every experience is a learning experience. As long as you continue to move forward, everything will be ok in the end.You must be strong. It is ok to take time to feel your emotions and process them. But if you let your past shape your personality and control your future, you will only experience hurt much longer than you have to. Your future belongs to you.

He will often be the one deciding things for you both to do, or get you to do what he wants. When it comes to intimacy such as sex then he may try to show interest and want to meet you and play on your feelings by using charm and playing the “nice gentleman”when his main intention is to try to have sex with you, and when it’s done and he’s satisfied, he may not contact you or show you so much interest until he feels the need for more sex. He may “wine and dine” you, buy you gifts, court you in different ways, all for the reason to get what he is really after -whats between your legs, and then show less interest or have less contact through phone calls, text messaging and social media afterwards. If you don’t know him that well or even after a couple of moments of contacting you, if some of the first words he says to you or in the first conversations mentions anything related to your body, that it’s sexy in different ways, then this is a pretty clear indication worth thinking about, about what he is really after and the only reason why he is having any kind of contact with you at all. He can be playing on your feelings by pretending to like you. He can tell you sweet things that will “tickle your ears” or make you feel like he is interested and tries to make you feel special, these tactics are quite common when trying to get someone in bed with them. There are many ways men can try to use someone, but sex can be the most common thing that they are after when they use someone. If you are wealthy then that is also something they will target. They can be charming and seem like the perfect guy and seem sincere, but they are doing it for their own selfish gain. Some may use people just so they have a place to live for the time being until they get things sorted out, and when they do, they’ll dump you and leave. If you are in some kind of position in a business or if you are involved in something that he also wants to be a part of, then men (as well as women) will also target you just to get to where they want to be in those areas or positions where they’ll profit somehow.

If they are clever enough, you won't now until they've already done the job and left!  Since taking advantage of people is generally done with craftiness and concealing both motives and methods, it's just plain not easy.  And once they've started (say, someone sells you siding for your home, then they say you have dry rot and need a whole new wall first, and they know JUST THE PERSON who can re-do your wall)... well, you can see that the question is more likely, "How can I detect craftiness and dishonesty so I don't get taken advantage of in the first place?"   Second opinions rate high on this list.  Red-flag emotional appeals ("I need the money from making this sale to get my wife a doctor's appointment...") are worth less than the cost of a red flag. References MUST be followed up on, and insisted upon, and don't be afraid to do some checking on your own (naturally, a deceiver will give you people in his camp).   Good actors are not just found on the stage; there are people who can get you to feel like you have known them all your life, without really telling you a single valid thing about themselves. You must decide, say, if someone habitually asks you for money or assistance of some sort, if you wish to give your money away totally freely - simply out of love for humanity, regardless of whether the appeal is genuine or a big lie.  If you wish to do so, you are freed from being taken advantage of, because you, not your emotions, are in control.  SubmitIn general, if you feel your emotions swishing from pro to con about the thing, it is likely your are being taken advantage of, or are about to be a victim. 85% of all people, said one survey I read but do not know where I read it, are completely trustworthy with money and your loved ones.  But 15% can do a huge stinking heap of damage:(  So how do you "know"?  Well, you actually make an educated guess -- but don't discount your native feelings, and if you're going to be a fall guy, be so because you can really be happy being taken advantage of.

Hi! I did not spell or grammar check this. Here are about 10–15 things from the top of my head. Hope it helps. Ask more here later. The questions was a bit too general/vague. It matters why the person feels their man is not interested… Their situation/circumstance. But here you go. He will almost never initiate first contacts. (Text, Email, Goodmorning, Call)Discussions/interactions will be impersonal or vague. He will seem rushed or hurried when you initiate with him (he will be distant).Interactions will be brief, infrequent and have specific objectives (lets meet to have sex, to do “X”, or go here). Lacking spontaneous/random feelHe wont ask “about you”. Questions like: ‘What do you think’, ‘how do you feel’, ‘how did that make you feel’ or “WHY do you think that”.—These are important personal questions anyone who cares knows.Often he will talk to you at specific or predetermined times (mechanical). He will call/txt at same times (quick/brief). They wont be spontaneous. This is because he does it when on a break because he feels he needs to. Not because he wants to.— He will have you call only at specific times or request you call him on schedule always (He is doing “more important things”) Make sense?He won’t touch you a lot, break the personal space barrier outside of sex. Kissing will be limited too outside of specific times. Hold hands almost never, his hand on your back; neck; hip or butt in public - NEVERA male who cares about works to earn your trust, respects you, is open to you and talks. You feel good talking to them and ask them thing/for help or advice (it is hardwired/natural). You ask your man for support. A male who does not like you rarely gives advice or has this with you.His compliments while great are very sexual. Often seemed a bit forced and the same type, “I love your X, Y, Z” over and over. You get the most compliments before sex/intimacyHe is not vulnerable to you. You are his girl/woman. He should ask for your help, love or support. He should let you make him feel better (non sexual) or take care of him. Just means guys who use you push you. They don’t seek your support, love or opinion.Finally one of the biggest: While society says we should not be. Men are shy, insecure or embarrassed. Sometimes we say / ask the wrong things or don’t ask the right ones. BUT if he is using you. Rarely will he talk about what you like intimately (sex). Rarely will he want to find out what turns you on. You usually feel it, he is not putting your needs first or thinking about them (physical, emotional or intellectual). He says the right things when intimate. He gets what he wants and goes within 60 min.

Right off, you answered it yourself. The difference between a BOY and a MAN is if they are using you or not. Being good in bed or fathering children doesn’t make a boy a man any more than having a penis does. So, if he’s a boy, he’s using you. Taking advantage. What do YOU get out of it? Great sex? Nah. He gets that too. Do you buy him clothes? Food? Beer? Cigarettes? If you seem to be giving all the time, and he’s taking, then you’re getting the short end of the deal. Even a poor man can give you something. Maybe he can’t take you everywhere or do things, but he can show he’s thinking about you. Do things you want to do, or try. He could buy you flower or pick them, it’s the thought here. But, if he only does things in public, where others can see, that’s different. If you’re pretty, you can be arm candy. In my experience, most boys, even at 40, are using women. Their wife, at home, is for sex when they need it, cooking, cleaning, and raising kids. Their mistress or girlfriend is to show off with, prove they can still handle women in bed, play you, and maybe even get you to shower them (!) with gifts. It used to be the other way around. A relationship is a two way street. Give AND take. If one of you is doing all the taking and the other all the giving, it isn’t a relationship. I hate to say it, but women tend to be right on this. Every man who hits on you is after sex. Using you to that end. The only difference is if he cares about you past this or not. Always be careful until you KNOW where he stands. And, often, that only happens after years of being married without him cheating on you.

If these things are happening, your intuition is trying to get your attention: 1- You see them coming in person, in text, in email, and you dread it each time. 2- Your energy is depleted way too fast when you are around them. 3- You have a sense that it’s their world and you just live in it. 4- You ask about them in your chats, but they never ask about you. 5- When they’re in a bind - you’re their primary go-to person to pull them out of a pinch, give advice, help paint a room, borrow books, magazines, etc…but they never return the favor…and probably didn’t return what they borrowed either. 6- You’re only invited to events with them that require you to give money or a gift. They never ask you to just be around them. 7- They attempt to spin what they need from you with a ‘Here’s what’s in it for you’ sales job and they’re entirely serious about it. 8- You see others getting the good stuff you long for from this person and you seem to only get crumbs or the requests requiring real work. 9- You feel lousy about yourself when you’re around them. You find yourself shrinking in their presence. 10- When you text them, they either don’t reply or take a very long time to reply - with no reason shared to show a bit of concern for your feelings with their tardiness. In and of itself - that’s not always a big deal. BUT THEN - when you stand in front of them and texts come in to them from others - you watch them respond immediately over and over … YEAH … you are not even kind of a priority in this person’s life. Why keep giving this person your time and resources? They are showing you all you need to know. Drop these kinds of people like a bad habit.

They contact you only when they need help. They don’t start casual conversation with you often but once in a while when they need you to do something in favor for them.They say “Thank You” to all the things you have done for them but never offer anything in return. Sometimes you help someone without any expectation of something back. However, it doesn’t mean “Thank You” is enough to make the relationship stay in harmony.They pay close attention to what you own and keep asking if they can have or try it someday such as your beautiful dress, your fancy sport car, or expensive watch. Of course, people may show admiration toward your valuable stuffs, but they usually give out the compliments and move on rather than asking if they can have a try.They start to ask more than what you’ve already given them without concerning about your irritation. Remember those people who like to take advantage of others are usually lacking of self-respect. Therefore, they like to focus on how to get more from your materials and ignore your feeling.They make you feel like you are the only one that can help them to get out of their own problems. They keep complaining about their own misery such as no job, no money, no one helping them and ask if you can offer help. If you don’t, they will start to blame that you’re not a good friend, you leave them struggled without any help and so on.They are interested in sharing only some information that they think you can help them. It is acceptable in acquaintance relationship, but not in good friendship or romantic relationship. For example, your boyfriend can ask if you want to pay 50/50 for the new treadmill so both of you can share it but never tell you anything about his new car purchase or work promotion.

They are sneaky. They will ask what you are doing, and if you answer them that you are going to the store they will ask for you to get them something. WHen you give them gas or laundry money they ask for more or try to get you to pity them. they drop in your house whenever they want. When you tell them to do something, such as don’t let the phone ring because your mom needs the phone because they are dying of Cancer they will do it anyway and let the phone ring. They try to get you to pay for them at restuarants and invite themselves to lunch. These people need to burn in hell. If you have known them for 20 years and have told them you are not up before noon and they drop in before noon anyway. They think that your father finds them attractive because you mentioned that a black singer like Tony Braxton was pretty. They have bad ugly, donkey teeth and their family hates them. They make 3 times more than you do and they still ask for food. . They sleep with underage boys and try to get them to feed them food despite them being near 40years old with a child and gapping vagina..You tell them you need to get home but they look like they want to beat you if you don’t take them where they want to go. You offer to take them to lunch and they order all these extra items. They drop in your house whatever time they want. They will take anything you can for them even when you have nothing and they make 4 times as much. They even drive and brand new car and live in a brand new house and still try to ask you for things when you don’t even have a car…. They need to burn in hell and they have no pride.

If you suspect the person is taking advantage of you, then they probably are. These kinds of doubts arise when the other person is doing something that sets off little warning bells. Examine the relationship, and see what is causing you to wonder about them. A person can take advantage of you in different ways: material, physical, emotional. Are you handing over a lot of money, expensive gifts, paying the other person’s bills? Is the other person treating you like a servant? Expecting you to cater to their needs and make them happy, as if it’s your job? Is the other person manipulating you sexually and misleading you? Is everything in the relationship pretty one-sided, with you being the one giving and the other person being the one who takes? If so, yes, the person is taking advantage of you. Do you have a high position, connections, social prestige, power that the other person is using to climb up the ladder and get ahead? Do you suspect that’s the primary reason the person wants to be with you? Would you be together if you didn’t have so much to offer? The way to avoid this is to set clear boundaries. Give what you are happy to give, and don’t give more than that. Expect some gratitude for favors you do. Expect the other person to treat you with the same courtesy and concern that you show toward them. Expect the relationship to be one of give and take. Don’t try to buy another person’s affection or respect by constantly giving things, doing things, sacrificing in order to make the other person like you. People need to like you for who you are, not what you give them or do for them.

In the long run, the lie will be unsustainable, and the truth will out. But by then you have been emotionally drained and hurt. What we want to know is how to find out immediately, before the damage is done. Problem is, there are many personality types, and bringing them together “Randomly” makes a score of different possibilities. I shall narrow the possibilities to a few generally common types, and then I will surprise you with an unexpected ending. The term “Con man” is known to refer to dishonesty. Of course, it is a contraction for “Confidence man”. The confidence man wins your trust and good faith by being a skillful actor and liar. Since a confidence man most often targets personality types that are dependent and trusting, it is quite easy for them to take advantage. In this case a vulnerable woman may not be able to make a determination on her own. I would recommend the women who know that they are too trusting in others, develop a support network with girlfriends and ask for their assistance in evaluating the gentleman. Arrange for a group activity with the ladies intention of determining The gentleman's intentions. Then come to a consensus of opinions and advice and trust your friends. Another personality type is the follower. The follower looks to a man to be in charge and control of the relationship and is happy to demure to the man's decision-making. In this case there will be some measured degree of difficulty in assessing the gentleman's intentions. It would be possible to simply review you're romantic needs and then take a vow or make a pact, that you will focus on the gentleman's behavior and diminish your own emotional responses for a temporary Period of time to allow yourself to make the assessment. Should this be to problematic, then follow the advice from the first personality type and get support from some sisters. One last type is the self confident and practical type who has a good chance of making the determination by careful observation. Things to look for would be little contradictions that indicate a false nature, it complex story to justify a suspicious situation, indicating a lie, and a gentleman who presents one face to people, but privately expresses Contrary indications. And now for the surprise ending. Romantic marriages as we know them in western culture have a rate of failure that is much higher then another kind of marriage more common in Eastern European countries and South American countries. The arranged marriage has a much higher success rate then the western romantic marriage. A common occurrence in an arranged marriage, is that the newlyweds do not love each other. But when questioned about their feelings it is also a common answer that they soon grow to love one another. The arranged marriage is not without love it just develops. So my surprise recommendation for preventing being taken advantage of by a scoundrel is this: determine a number of persons that you trust or possibly love and ask them to make marriage recommendations for you. The reason arranged marriages work so well is because those who arrange them know the personalities and wants and desires of the people involved. Trust those who love you and know you to steer you in the right direction. The truth shall set you free.

You feel guilty for thinking about your needs when you are in the presence of the people taking advantage of you cause they have manipulated you in such a way like showing disappointment when you put forward your reasonable needs.The person only comes to you when they need you help and otherwise not reciprocate when you need their help or not even keep contact with you other than the time they need your help. At times these people can even talk negatively behind your back.If you have refused the person for something they might keep on insisting or getting after you to do something or even blackmail you (do this if you are my friend) or get angry if you refuse to comply with them or behave passive aggressively with you. Some might even use labeling to convince you to do something like they may say don't be such a boring person or you are scared/timid person or you are not cool.In order to avoid this firstly if you have a gut instinct that these people are not good don't ignore it. Secondly set healthy boundaries like think of what behavior is acceptable and unacceptable to you and stick to your those things. When you disagree to do something be firm about it and stick to refusing it don't change you mind if they try to persuade you to do something. Because if you give in once chances are they will keep on using various strategies to continue to convert your no to a yes, and the next time it would be for bigger requests. Disappointment is another thing they will show often to change your mind often initially when you set a boundry. Don't let that change your mind. If you consistently set boundaries firmly (by firm I am not trying to say be rude or anything instead you need to be polite but firm) they will eventually adjust with it.

Yes, and this came from the experiences of getting taken advantage of. I used to be a really nice guy and still am to an extent (although more careful), and I was always willing to help someone if I felt they needed it. This could range from small amounts of money to letting someone stay over my house to giving rides, etc. When someone is taking advantage of me it can be a bit obvious, because those that don’t take advantage of my kindness behave differently. Those who take advantage will usually not compensate you, an example is giving someone a ride and they don’t give you gas money, or even think to offer it. On the other hand, my friends would have offered the gas money and appreciated the favor. Like someone else has said, the best way to know if you’re being taken advantage of is saying “no” and seeing how they react. A normal person would take the no and leave it at that, and they may be disappointed. But someone who is taking advantage will be upset that you didn’t do what they wanted, and will try many methods to convince you to do something. Guilt and pity are common tactics, and sometimes they’ll claim they did something for you (which could be exaggerated or simply fabricated), therefore you have an obligation to them. This is a form of manipulation. Try to tally the amount of favors you’ve done for them and the amount they’ve done for you. If the gap is large that tells you something. And if their behavior tends to be more hostile and selfish instead of appreciative, you’re being taken advantage of.

Does he seek emotional intimacy with you, wanting to hear about your ideas and thoughts on different things, your dreams and ambitions, and anything else under the sun that you may want to share with him, asking questions rather than you just having to bring things like this up? Does he respect what you share with him, even if he may not agree with some things, so you make an emotional safe place for both of you to really get to know each other without fear of criticism or being put down? Secondly, is he proud to be out in public with you, not afraid to hold your hand and show other forms of normal public affection? Is he excited for you to meet the other people in his life, like his parents, siblings, friends, etc.? Third, is he reliable, such as if he cancels plans with you, does that only happen for very good reasons? If it seems to be habitual, that's a good sign that you aren't someone he respects. Never, ever let someone be your priority when for them you are merely an option… you deserve better! If you've been with him a reasonable amount of time, and this isn't happening, I'd say that he's not the fella for you and you should move on… natures abhors a vacuum, and you won't meet Mr. Right if you're spending any time or energy on Mr. Wrong. I wish you the best of luck, and I hope you find the man for you… please don't settle, because you deserve the full package, not just a part of it… as everyone does.

Taking advantage of someone means that they have something you want or need (either a skill, cash, or an item) and you come up with a way to get them to give it to you without thinking about whether or not they really want to hand it over. Example: you meet a new person and they have a T-shirt you would almost kill for. You immediately plot a way to get them to give you the T-shirt. OR sometimes people take advantage of someone for the hellof it. Like most people I’ve done some crappy things in my life but the one that bothers me the most was one time when I took advantage of someone in eighth grade. It was someone without any friends, and I pretended to like them just so I could walk away and make them feel bad. To this day, I wish I could remember the guy’s name, it has haunted me for years. Since that day, I totally try not to do anything like that. So if you were a geeky guy in junior high in August Georgia who was really into Mandel’s pea experiments and finally met someone who could share your interest….who seemed to make friends and then totally walk away laughing….I’m sorry. You impacted my life more than you will ever know.

People learns from their mistakes while a clever person learns from others, with that said, I'm going to answer this without the experience of dating jerks. Hes not showing you any emotional affection.He’s known for his reputation.You can tell his character by his choice of friends.How often does he text you? Is he always flirting when he finally comes round or does he flirting with other women? Does he text you often or is it always at night when he's lonely?Does he genuinely like spending time with you? Is he willing to go shopping with you? The park with you? Your aunts house to pick up your nephews with you?Does he tell you how he feels for you daily or often?Is he known for being like a jerk or unfaithful?When he is with you is he alwayd trying to hit on you?Is he seeing someone making you the side chick?Is the relationship one sided?If you've answered 1–2 yes then you both need to work on the relationship. 3+ Hes using you. You can always say “Obviously this relationship isn't going to work out in the long run and I'm not content in this relationship. We're breaking up” Let his whine and cry but dont change your answer.

Paying for everything off top. You’ll start with little shyt like takeout , or items from a grocery store because you like him and “oh it’s nothing”, then it’ll be paying for full dinners, drinks at a bar and date nights because “it isn’t his pay week” or he’s”short on cash this week” or “I got you next time” type crap.Asking to move in with you. He’ll contribute for the first two or three months and you’ll think everything is fine. Then, slowly but surely, he’ll start falling behind on payments. See reasons above.Never buying you anything but ALWAYS has money for what HE wants. It could be something as simple as asking him to bring you something to eat. He says I don’t have it, but comes home with a fresh haircut, cigarettes or whatever he smokes, and his favorite bottle of liquor.These are just some of the situations I’ve witnessed with gf’s over the years. Have the courage to get rid of them before they bleed your pockets and your soul dry. If you don’t make them go, they won’t. It’s not because they love you, it’s just that some men will use the f**k outta you because they know when they have a sucker on their hands.

There are a few ways to spot a player - someone who just wants you for sex and is in no way interested in a serious relationship: They never introduce you to their friends or family.They don’t want to meet your friends or family.They only want to meet at their place, or yours.They avoid going anywhere with you in public.They give you frequent booty calls at odd hours of the day.If you say that you’ll only sleep with a guy after dating them for a long time - they’re outta there!When you meet up, they have a one-track mind - how to get you into bed - and all of their actions and words are pointed towards getting there.They won’t make any future plans with you.They will say anything to get you into bed and be super flattering.They will think that all of the above is very normal behavior, or give you some dumb reason for pointing any of it out.They won’t be very interested in getting to know you better as a person, and only talk about superficial topics.There are many more, but these are at the top of my head.

manipulation. this one is always hard for the victim to spot so here are some versions of manipulation to look out for: guilt tripping, suicide bating, using emotions against youcontrolling behavior. he has to know where youre at, what youre doing at all times or else be gets mad at you.asking for a lot of favors. this one should be self explanatory. not like “can i borrow some sugar” or “can i borrow something out your tool box" more like “can i borrow $500?” “can i please stay at your place for a month? i cant afford rent" this has to be consistent for him to be taking advantage of you.he seems to only want you around for specific times. for example, at school he might use you for popularity. he will hangout with you all the time, but when it comes to after school, he never calls or texts and doesnt want to hangout with you.he got with you directly after something negative happened. maybe his girlfriend broke up with him and now he is using you to get her jealous. maybe he just got laid off and is using you as free rent and money. maybe he is using you to get towards a better life with no plans of keeping you in that future. recognize the situation you are in.

When they no longer wants to spend or make time with you after you’ve help them with some dire situation they are in. They are nice and show interest when they want something, yet, when the service is done, they ignore/avoid you or show lack of concern for you. Ghosting is a big sign. They don’t have the nerve to talk to you in person even after all the help you’ve given. Sometimes when you say you can help with such and such, they want to jump at the opportunity so quick you know something is up. A red flag lights up in the back of your mind. Of course , the kind guy that you are, you ignore the signs because you think this person can be a good real friend. It’s not that you don’t want to help them. You would of done it anyways. Just sucks that they bail after they got help. And your left alone thinking, why did i help such and such. Every time i help someone, i get the short stick. Sooo goes another tally that tells you good deeds waste your time and goes no where. Then you lost your desire to help others in the future just cuz people aren’t grateful for your help.

I have a long and inglorious history of being taken advantage of in my life. Friends trying to feed me to their dog, friends who stole my toys, friends who convinced me that bullies wanted to just “talk things over” and who then went on to steal more of my and my brothers things. Classmates who would try to get me to do their homework for them, give them rides and girls who loved to have me give them massages, fix their cars, make them food and help thier families. I'm pretty good at recognizing it now. Another phrase for taking advantage of somebody is “using them”. This is distinctly different from people who are investing in a relationship with you. Investing is a mutual thing. You put in something with the hope that it grows, when it grows you grow. When you part ways both of you are better. Users dont care about your growth. They don't care about your needs. So to find out which is which ask for some help. Make it small, make it commensurate with requests you've recieved from them. If they balk, if they make excuses and they continue to do so well you have your answer. Theyre using you.

There are two kinds of people who will take advantage of you. First, there are the people who are obviously taking advantage of you. You can just tell. They use all kinds of tactics to get you to do what you don't want to do.  But the people whom you really need to watch out for are the slick ones. Their story is too well crafted. They very skillfully manipulate your feelings. They are too sincere. They know just how to gain your sympathy.  They always have a perfect answer to questions you ask. They want you to act right now (because they know that if you think about it, you will realize that they are taking advantage of you).  Tell them you need to think about it, and see how they react. The signs are always there, but you might not see them until you've had some time to put together the pieces. Tell them you have a personal policy to not give immediate answers.

It is usually pretty clear. And you wouldn’t be asking this unless it was happening.* The problem is your reluctance to see it (denial) because it means you would have to do something about it, and you are too afraid of rocking the boat relationship-wise. You fear that if you ask for fairness and to be treated with respect, you will just get dumped. I can tell you from concrete experience, it is better to stand up for yourself and get dumped. You will feel bad about the breakup, but you will feel much better about yourself and your ability to take care of yourself When a guy is taking good care of you and being respectful, you would NEVER think to wonder if you are being used. I also have experience with this. The difference is night and day. Having experienced being treated with respect and love, now I would NEVER tolerate being used. That guy would be gone so fast, his head would still be spinning a week later.

Using someone for your own personal gain. Typically the person being used doesn't realize it (not at first at least) and the one using realizes that they wouldn't. This is very common in “friendships.” For example: Jack goes up to Tom and ask “Hey. Wanna be my friend?” Tom accepts. One day Jack says to Tom “Hey Tom, I forgot my lunch money. Can you spot me? I promise I will pay you back.” Tom thinks sure, I will help my friend. But this happens again and again and again without Tom ever being reimbursed. Tom may realize it eventually and tell him that he can't give him money anymore and chances are Jack would tell him he's a bad friend and never talk to Tom again but really there was no friendship, just Jack using Tom. Some more examples are: An addict, beggar, or bum telling you some fictional story to score some money.A guy telling a girl he loves her just to get in her pants.Someone making up lies or excuses to their “friend” so they will do their homework for them.

They’ll ask something which makes you uncomfortable and won’t take no for an answer. He says; Let me use your car. You Say; You don’t have a license. He says; I just want to get us some beer. Five minutes. I need some money. You say; You’re not covered by insurance. It’s my mom’s car! He says; You don’t trust me? and it goes on and on. Watch your money. The promise to pay you back later for some profit now is always suspect. “Give me ten bucks now. I get a check Friday. I’ll pay you back then.” You have two choices. Consider the money a gift and never expect it back, or write up a simple pair of contracts that both of you sign. Judge Marilyn Millian often says ‘Money should not change hands until you have a receipt, even if all you have is toilet paper and a crayon.” another wise bit of advice.. ‘Never lend money to a friend. You lose the friend and the money.’

When they are using you in some way, or not being grateful for you. That could be many situations. They may take advantage of your good nature by not following through with a promise, for instance, because they know you’ll “understand “ or forgive them. They may use or “borrow” money, or expect you to pay for everything if you have money, for another example. They may try to use you sexually, if you allow it. I think the fact that you’re asking this question is a red flag. I think the answer is to have boundaries and say no. Also, notice what he does and does not do for you. A person who takes advantage of others is usually a taker, not a giver. It should be mutual give & take. Does he thank you for nice things you do, or does he expect it? Go with your intuition and set boundaries, say no, or run. That’s just my opinion.

It's an interesting question. I do a lot of volunteer work. So, in essence, many people have ‘taken advantage‘ by something I've done. That's a good thing. I had an opportunity to give of myself, someone feels helped by it, and I feel good about having been helpful. But usually when someone expresses feeling taken advantage of, they mean it negatively. They are feeling ‘used’. That's not a good thing. No one can ‘take advantage of you’ without your consent. What I mean is that you have had to be a participant in it. Often when a person feels used is because they have given of themselves and feel unappreciated. Or they have given of themselves disproportionately. In either case, the person has consciously or unconsciously allowed themselves to be taken advantage of. Sometimes it's because of wanting to be liked. Sometimes it's because of low self-esteem. Best solution is to give of yourself freely and honestly, but only to the extent that you choose. Learn how to say ‘no’.

Hmmm. People repeat their patterns of behavior, unless they have thought them out and decided where they need to make a change. So, look at the interactions surrounding and leading up to the last time this party took advantage of you. When you look back at what happened, can you pinpoint when you lost advantage? If you’re in the middle of interactions with this party, and are unable to see what is going on clearly, there is every reason to stop what is going on. You have every right to say, “I am not comfortable with what you are saying / suggesting. I am leaving this discussion.” You have every right to leave any gathering where you are uneasy about the possibility of being taken advantage of. You have every right to tell any person you don’t trust, that they talk a good game, however, you want the time to do your own research, and to stop pressuring you. Be ready to walk away. Protect yourself!

Once a friend was desperate to know if her new boyfriend had serious intentions with her or was just using her. She wouldn’t stop talking about it and at some point I’d had enough. I told her next time he calls asking to meet, to agree wholeheartedly and later, while coordinating the time, to mention in passing that her car is at the mechanics for a few days. Then observe his reaction. (if you’re curious about the end of the story: she liked the idea, put it in practice and the guy’s reaction was to tell her to call him whenever she had the car again. She dumped him. I had been sure all along that he was using her for the car, but had never told her my feelings)

People get taken advantage of when they are compelled to perceive an offer or situation to be in their favor when, in fact, it's not. Here are some signs that a seemingly good offer is not in your best interest:  If something seems to good to be true.If someone is trying to make you feel like you're taking advantage of them / getting a great deal / etc.If someone is trying to get you to do something using flattery or any basis other than the merits of thing itself. If an offer seems out of line with the motivation of the person offering it (e.g. "great investment opportunities" - if it's so great, why is the person telling you about it rather than doing it themselves?). It's a safe assumption that, unless you are very close with someone, they are not going out of their way to find and help you out of the goodness of their heart.

If you always find your boundaries being pushed and feeling pressured into things, it's probably because your being taken advantage of. These are some questions you should ask yourself. Are they always asking for more and more, but are never showing appreciation? Do they reciprocate and give back to you in other ways? Are they over dramatic or emotional (could be emotionally manipulating you)? Are they cold and not there for you emotionally but then asks for so much from you? If you find yourself putting a lot more effort for the other person than they are for you, then maybe you should be honest with them in a non-confronting way first to see what they say. It's up to you to feel with intuition if they are being genuine or not. Also, actions speak louder than words.

I think you’re encoding your meaning in the question. All partners are seeking advantage, it’s why we live in the idioms we do ( a dashing lord to an untouched beauty, from an youthful energy to the mature and knowledgeable) all these relations have an element of advantage taking. So on that level, if his lips are moving he’s seeking advantage. As you are, here gathering evidence to either absolve yourself or to mount an attack on the advantage seeker. It seems what your asking is when does seeking advantage become nefarious manipulation? My answer is about balance. If two dramatic liars have a tempestuous relationship I don’t see anything wrong with that, but if one of those is with a meek “hero” personality, they will continually be the victim. So that’s my line. So it depends on the girl/guy. But that said: if you see a girl say no and a guy not listening… deal with that right there loudly and publicly.

If he… Is only calling you when he is drunk, high, or boredIgnores you when he is around or with his friendsRepeatedly asks you to send nudesRepeatedly asks if he can send you nudesDoesn’t want to commit himself to a relationship with youTalks about other girls to/near youDoesn’t make an effort to be seen in public with youAvoids being seen in public with youTexts you at odd or infrequent hoursIs constantly finding ways to bring sex into the conversation…then he is using you. Learn from my mistakes; get yourself out of that mess and hit b l o c k.

It means to get someone to do something for you without them getting anything out of it, and to do so more than just once in a while. For instance, if I ask you to stop by the store and pick up some milk on your way home, you would probably think nothing of it — the first time. If, once I realized how willing you were to do this sort of thing, I started asking you to pick up my dry cleaning, buy me some beer, and by the way, my friend is giving me his old TV could you stop by and pick it up for me — all without reimbursing you or trying to compensate you in any way — I am taking advantage of your generous nature.

How you can tell if a guy is using you? He leaves clues or blatant signs he just dosen't care. He won't call, always be late, not even show up and probably want just sex from a relationship. He'll treat you bad. Some guys do this in degrees. It starts subtle at first. Forgets to call or text. May flirt with other girls. Wont take you out. Won't talk to you when you try to sort out the relationship. One big sign is that you are MISERABLE!!! A guy who cares wouldn't want you to be unhappy. Just leave if you feel you are used…cause you probably are!!! Guys aren't that busy. They'll make time for someone they like/love. Good Luck!

If it requires sacrifice to you without gain, then I would consider hesitating to do it. If you say no and the other person is argumentative, then they’re not respecting your boundaries appropriately. If you don’t gain anything from it, then it’s not equal exchange. Regardless if a person is needed without malicious intent or if they’re taking advantage of you, a cost to you is a cost to you. And if a person doesn’t appreciate that and respect your boundaries, then it’s not good either way. But if you really want to know. If a person is needy, they will likely treat everyone who can meet said need the same way. If they’re taking advantage of you specifically, they might not treat others the same way.

Well your first indication, depending on your level of self-awareness, is simply just the feeling of being taken advantage of. You do a friend a favor without being concerned about reciprocity because doing favors is part of friendship. But if the requests keep coming and take up a significant part of your available time without your being compensated - either in money or in offering/or doing a return favor - then the relationship feels unbalanced by taking up time that could be used for work, relaxation, family time, social occasions. I think it’s largely about time, as in the saying “your time is a non-renewable resource”, because money or some other resource can always be replaced, but your time, once it is spent, cannot.

When someone calls you only when they need money or a ride somewhere, they're using you. They're the ones who beg you to help them move to their new apartment. But when you need help moving, they ignore your texts and calls. They will outright say they're too busy. They are the same people who invite you to their party and you wind up serving their guests and cleaning up afterward. You buy a gift together for a mutual friend and they never pay you back. I think you catch my drift. We've all been there. What we need to learn is to have a spine and say, “No!”

IMO I think only few would instantly perceive that they are being taken advantage because people has a blind spot for people they meet and people, with all the delusions and deceits they carry with them, evolves throughout the time. It is indeed hard to distinguish people if they are good or bad but it doesn’t mean that it’s impossible. You have to be the type who’s really cautious or observant when meeting people even if it’s just from a small talk or common gestures. Based on my experience, most of the people who likes to take advantage of someone are one-sided, they lack of empathy and they often sugar-coat their words. Some would say that they are afraid of commitment and they do not trust people very well may it be about the information they have or the capabilities of the person.

Using you how? There are many ways that someone can be used, but I'll try to list off a few warning signs. -If he makes you pay for almost every thing; he's a piece of crap and using you for your money. -If he doesn't act interested in having genuine conversations with you; he probably only wants you for a sexual relationship. He won't be around for long term. -If he only wants to sleep with you, but not interested in having a relationship; he's using you. -If he only wants to come over at night.. -I also know a guy that said he takes girls out to fancy restaurants just to get laid and gets mad if he doesn't get what he wants after spending a lot of money. If this is the case; he's using you.

It doesn't matter if you're being taken advantage of, because one way or other people take advantage of someone. Give and take in a relationship, child having to take care of their parents, employees in a company, same. The thing that matters is when it starts to get toxic and then what you choose to do about it, if you let someone keep on taking advantage of you, you're wrong, if you decide to stand up to it, you win. Just steer clear of your boundaries, and not let someone take more than they should.🌻

The biggest clue as to whether or not someone is using you has to do with the give and take of a relationship. Are you giving more than you’re receiving? Are you always texting first? If you aren’t, do they just text you when they want something?Do you seem to always be doing something for them? Yet, they pay you almost no attention?Are you always inviting them to things, and they’re never inviting you?These are just a few examples of what that would look like in a relationship (friends, partners, etc.) and there are plenty more.

The “too good to be true” offer screams “scam” to me. And the person’s energy. I notice those who are trying to take advantage are always too attached to the outcome they’re pushing. I also don’t invest much in relationships with people I don’t know well. I’ve known some people who are basically con artists and sometimes they can be fun to hang out with. They’re often quite charming especially when they are trying to get you to give them money, etc. As long as I keep clear boundaries, I’m fine.

When there is a one way flow of resources. "Resources" can be anything from money to advice or time. When you are giving up things and the other person is not giving up anything they are taking advantage of you. Everyone is in a position to take part in this flow of resources, even if it's just a genuine inquiry about your well being. The point here though is sincerity. Anyone can ask how you are and stop listening or replying after a few exchanges. This shows that they don't really care about you, they only care about what you can give them.

If you can’t tell that someone is taking advantage of you… whoa to you, because word will get out and there will be a long line of moochers behind them waiting to take advantage of you next. Sometimes it’s easier for others to see what you can’t. If you think someone is taking advantage of you, that is a strong indication that they are. If you need corroboration, ask another person what they think of the situation.

Women often do this to men. Many women, if they know a man likes them, will make him take her out and pay for anything/everything (dinners, gifts, hotels stays, holidays). They often won’t sleep with the guy so he is not sure if she even likes him romantically. Men do this the opposite way, they use a woman’s love to get sex with her and then disappear. Women who love a man don’t withhold sex from him (they don’t want to because they want him sexually and cannot resist him). And a man who loves you, doesn’t use you for sex (he wants a romantic relationship with you as well as sex). Notice I am talking about women and men, not girls and boys, this advice relates to consenting adults.

When people see they can take advantage of you they are using you for their own purpose. For example: I had a male friend who only called when his vehicle broke down or he and his wife weren’t able to come over for dinner because they either couldn’t find a babysitter or didn’t want to pay for one or just didn’t feel like going out of their way to attend the dinner. Hence we would make the effort to visit them “all-of-the-time”! That in my opinion was taking advantage of us.

What does that even mean? If you have a relationship with a man and you agree to sleep with him, you are using him as much as he is using you. If he asked you for money, and you give it to him without a written agreement for repayment, then you are using him as much as he is using you. If you are dating him with the idea that you will marry him in the future without that being a spoken expectation, then you are using him as much as he is using you. The only time he might be really using you is if you spoke an expectation, he said he would meet it, but it was a lie. When you discover the lie, that is when you will be able to tell if a man is using you. But if you have unspoken expectations, then you may be using him.

One of the effective first steps in knowing this is to see the reactions of those whom you suspect are taking advantage of you when you refuse to do something in their favor (especially something that sucks a lot of your time, money, and energy). The ones who are taking advantage of you will start getting frustrated, angry, manipulative, play victims, etc. If you are not convinced – try it again some other time – and document their reactions. And the best way – consult the situation with your friends, family, mentors, or anyone whom you are close to. Those that care about you will tell you honestly what they think of your situation.

Not every woman (or man) can always tell if someone is trying to take advantage of their weaknesses. My question to you is why would a man WANT to take advantage of a woman’s weaknesses? It clearly expresses that particular man has his own weakness’s that are in dire need of repairing if he is thinking these types of thoughts to begin with. Which will ultimately lead to heartache and pain and anger and a whole big melting pot of drama down the road for both parties. So seriously…why think that way at all?

How can you tell if a guy is using you? Tell him he is cut off from all benefits except for companionship and friendship, no money, no borrowing, no “adult relations”, nothing given to him but friendship, understanding, all the intangibles. See how long he sticks around. That will work, but be upfront and tell him why, don't just turn cold. Explain why you are changing the rules for a time. A lack of understanding here means a lack of affection.

This is sort of easy. The only interest he has in you is sexual.He never takes you anywhere.He does not introduce you to his friends or family.He is constantly broke and asking you for money or to pay for things he wants.he bullies you into doing things you don’t really want to do.he shows no consideration for your feelings or your likes and dislikes.When you have relations he has no interest in whether or not you are enjoying it as long as he is getting off.The list could go on, but I think this should be enough to get the point across.

It’s a fine line between knowing someone very well and taking them for granted. Simplistically, being taken for granted is not being asked if you want to do something. But it can be very nice if your partner plans something without your knowledge, thinking you will like it. And getting it right. My girlfriend once tried to reminisce with me about our holiday in Austria together. I pointed out that I had never been there. She thought harder and realised that she had been with a previous boyfriend. Now, should I be pleased that I was such a part of her life that her time with this previous boyfriend was forgotten or annoyed that she took it for granted that it was me ? I decided to be happy that I was the generic boyfriend.

My personality is that I think negatively and to pay close attention to my intuition. So my answer would be that if you have to ask the question, you are being used. Simple as that. But then again, maybe you have a tinge of paranoia because you have very low self-esteem. Either way, if you feel you want to continue this relationship, do it with the mindset that you are “exploring” it rather than committing to it. You can’t be used if you continued the relationship mindful of the possible outcomes and that it was your choice. I have to mention that as part of your awareness, you should be familiar with the signs of an abusive relationship so that you can get out and get help.

It can mean a lot of things. To take advantage of someone, you use something that you know will be hard for them to resist to get them to do what you want. For example, you want steak for dinner but don’t have the money. Instead of asking for money for steak, you say I don’t have money to buy food for my kids, knowing they wouldn’t let your kids go hungry.

He cares little about you. He is allways waiting for your hospitality to be shown. Although that person has the means to survive, he will allways exploit you and you will feel drained. He never returns with anything back, not even gratitude. He takes for granted what you offer. He is self-entitled. He will allways make a fuss about the value of merchandise, but never in your benefit. A person with little means, but with high morals, will decline or make rare at eating of your goodness that you provide. He will make his step rare in your house, because he respects you, and wants your friendship and not your hatred.

One of the ways would be if he push you around on the carpet while he makes racecar sounds. My apologies if my previous statement comes across as mean. I know refer to playing with your feelings or with you emotionally, but there are a lot of different ways he can do that, so many in fact that I would rather not even bother to go into some hypothetical examples. That's why I went for the racecar statement because it would be just as ridiculous. Why don't you at least describe what he does. Read your question and pretend that a random stranger just asked you this question. Would you be able to answer the person?

Contrary to what one might think rational people who are routinely using you  tend to become contemptuous rather than sweetness and light  they become rude demanding ungrateful and critical if you have a real " need to know" simply be passive and over agreeable decent people will self limit out of respect users will only be as decent as you force them to be if you allow them enough  latitude to abuse your passivity they will very quickly reveal thier character or lack of it.

Every time they call, visit or text you, they ask a favor?There are some people who are really smart and wait a few more days after getting in contact with you, before throwing the grenade. Just ask yourself,  what are you gaining from the relationship?Are you become closer? Getting great advices? Do you think the other person cares about you?Have you asked for favors  to the other person? If yes, have you received any help? And the most important question;  What would happen if you were unable to help the other person? They/he/she would still in contact with you?  Remember. This your life, so you choose the people who you spend your time with.

-When he is only sweet to you in front of his friends, ex-girlfriends and even his parents. When the two of you become alone, he aren't sweet anymore. -When he only need you when he wants something from you. -When he does not care about you and your feelings and care more about himself. This is not base on my experience (NBSB here!). This is base on what I see with my girl friends guy and what I read and what I watch on television ^_^. So, when you experienced all of this or at least one, you should avoid that kind of guy.

• He doesn’t want to hang out with you. •He sends very few messages a day and they are short and boring. •He keeps asking you to do something; actually demanding you to do it. •He makes you feel bad and good about yourself at the same time. My advice: you should test him. Do something that he doesn’t like and see how he reacts.

I can when I know someone is trying to make me pity them (online fights) I had a very manipulative friend online and she tried getting me to pity her because she said she told my friends things she utterly regrets but I know she was feeding bull shit when she said my friend was talking shit about her and caught her. My friend doesn’t do that without a really good reason so knew she was bullshitting me. Especially when I know my friend very well. That’s how I know someone I know or not know is trying to manipulate me and feed me crap. I know who they’re talking about well.

What are the signs that someone is beginning to take advantage of you? They are constantly making suggestions about your appearance or wanting something from you or creating a conflict within you when you start to doubt yourself. What I had just commented is also for those being abused by narcissists which is what happened to me from someone who is devious and know how to use your vulnerability.

If you look up the meaning of Advantage and then use an opposite you would have your answer. Using them, treating them like a personal bank, slave, whatever you want them to do for you. Example - Asking people to drive you here there and everywhere and not offering to help with the petrol costs. - Keep asking to borrow money and never pay them back and so on. Using them is the best way to describe it.

Answer Yes or no to the following questions: Have you met his parents yet? If you have not, then I question your judgement: You really don’t know what he’s all about. Are you invited to any sports events ( if he’s on a team)? NO? Not good. Are his friends at least civil to you?If they’re not, be worried.) Last but not least, does he talk about his future plans ( what his field of interest is, career wise?) If all the answers are negative, then go to a medical clinic and get tests run if indeed you’ve had sex with him.

It’s not always possible to know this, at least initially. And once it becomes apparent, things will change. But I tend to look at this in light of my own reasons for helping someone. Once I have committed myself to giving either my help or perhaps some other form of aid, because I am doing it in the name of the Lord Jesus, it is then out of my hands. What the receiver of the help does with it, is then their responsibility. I have done my part and I don’t have to police it or worry about it any further.

If he tells you sweet nothings and seems interested in other women. If he insinuates sex or related topics in every other conversation. If you are in a situation where you are enabling him. If he doesn't seem to care about your feelings a lot of times. 3 or more of these. Also, you could also be playing him. If that's the case all are null and void.

You probably can’t be sure, since there are many different ways you might be used and some people would be fine with it because they feel they’re getting other benefits, information, experience, whatever. The most common is being asked to do stuff way out of sync with or more than your job description (if you even have one) and not paid anything different from what was committed to. You have to expect some stuff that is outside of normal, but if it starts to be a big portion then time to ask for a raise or a different spot in the organization.

If a guy is just playing he will be extra nice and will accept you completely and will not try to understand you and give honest opinion on your thoughts. he will just go with the flow and if this guy really likes you he will try to understand you and also give you his honest opinion on things or thoughts, and will put more efforts to know you better.

Just think…… think and count that how many times they have been a help to you or they made you happy or you loved their company or they thought of you when they were doing something intresting or happening or times when you took the initiative and then things that you did for them and you will get the answer . :)

You don’t, because if you did, it wouldn’t/couldn’t happen. So it takes reflection and checking in with yourself. Do you feel good with this person. Can you distinguish between use and abuse? It took me decades to figure that a friend was abusing and not using me… it wasn’t all the time and it wasn’t material. No money exchanged, but the emotional exchange was imbalanced. But there were little meannesses and witholdings that accumulated. She didn’t act like other friends. The best users are subtle. So think, compare take good care of yourself.

you shouldn’t be in a position of being used unless a companion or partner has already past the test of commitment and sincerity and you have spent time together so that you have seen various behaviors and lived through some issues and have a solid feeling of whether the person can be trsuted or not, if you have given yourself to someone before knowing whether you could trust them you have made a mistake

When they only call you when they need your help. When they don't ever act like they miss you or seek your company unless they're bored. When they always make you do things for them without returning the offer. When they are never there for you when you need them. They're a lot more though.

“to take advantage” means he is misleading for ulterior motives that would lead to a negative effect in the girl for his own benefit. Its not hard, look for ulterior motives. If you dont trust him, you shouldnt be with him anyway. In most cases, this means be weary before 25, because most children have very little mental capacity to think for anything but themselves, even if they dont think they are.

You know when a person is playing head games with you. Ask the person to come do some little thing for you and see how many excuses they come up with. Ask them for something other than sex that they have asked you for even if you don't need it.

The one thing I’ve found that helps, is when someone asks me for personal information (whether online or in person) I always ask them one standard question in reply: “Why do you want to know?” Or if they want more service, more money, more information than was originally given to them, again, I ask why. It may not be the most friendly way to deal with people, but I have avoided many uncomfortable or even intrusive people who would want to take advantage of me by using this technique.

When a guy has other girlfriends .His phone is always off on weekends .Talks to you or sees you during the week. You get excuses like phone was broken , phone fell in water .phone stolen. Hvingers flue voice hoarse can't talk Suddenly gets better. He just satisfy his ego with you .Time to move away and get on with your life .

It is nothing but USING them :D or USE them when needed and not even ask them if they need any help in return or if not asked help them out of happiness in return. This is like having a “friend” in contact who is resourceful and contact that friend when needed and not contact the friend for any other purpose other than to get a help. Cheers

When they don't care about your feeling, don't reply to your messages more often , start lying and make silly excuses when you ask them why they didn't pick up your call.  Instead of all that if you are still there to help them at first symptom of problem and after the problem get solved ,  they just treat you like a "friend" in need

Are you being asked to stay late and come in early without pay? Are you being forced to give your weekends away? Are you doing the work for someone else that has been assigned to them and not getting recognized for it? If your answer was NO to those questions than you are not being taken advantage of - the workplace is a place where someone hires you to work for them and pays you for your services. If you don’t believe you are being paid fairly, than either ask for a raise or look elsewhere. It should feel like a quid pro quo - you get money - they get your skills.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by John J. Niece
